title: How Effective Is PrEP for Preventing HIV and AIDS?
author: Paul Frysh

sections.heading: What Is PrEP for HIV?
content: PrEP is medicine that helps protect you from HIV. It stands for pre-exposure prophylaxis.
This is in contrast to treatment for people who either have signs of the virus in their blood (are HIV-positive) or already have symptoms linked to the illness.
Learn how PrEP works, who can benefit from the medication, and about side effects of PrEP.
bullets: “Pre” means before. You take the medicine before you think you might come into contact with HIV.
“Exposure” means contact with HIV.
“Prophylaxis” means treatment to stop HIV infection in the first place.

content_blocks.text: PrEP is medicine that helps protect you from HIV. It stands for pre-exposure prophylaxis.

items: “Pre” means before. You take the medicine before you think you might come into contact with HIV.
“Prophylaxis” means treatment to stop HIV infection in the first place.

content_blocks.text: This is in contrast to treatment for people who either have signs of the virus in their blood (are HIV-positive) or already have symptoms linked to the illness.
Learn how PrEP works, who can benefit from the medication, and about side effects of PrEP.

sections.heading: How PrEP Medications Work
content: PrEP stops HIV from taking hold in your body and spreading. If PrEP works as intended, you should not become HIV-positive.

The FDA has approved two pills and two injectable medicines for PrEP. FTC/TDF (Truvada) is the main pill that doctors prescribe. It combines two medicines – emtricitabine (FTC) and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) – to block an enzyme the virus needs to make copies of itself in your body. Truvada is prescribed for those at risk for HIV from either sex or drug use.

content_blocks.text: PrEP stops HIV from taking hold in your body and spreading. If PrEP works as intended, you should not become HIV-positive.

The FDA has approved two pills and two injectable medicines for PrEP. FTC/TDF (Truvada) is the main pill that doctors prescribe. It combines two medicines – emtricitabine (FTC) and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) – to block an enzyme the virus needs to make copies of itself in your body. Truvada is prescribed for those at risk for HIV from either sex or drug use.

content: The second pill, FTC/TAF (Descovy), isn't prescribed for those assigned female at birth. That's because it's unclear if the drug protects against HIV transmission if you have sex through your vagina.
Both and Descovy and Truvada are daily pills.

Another PrEP drug, cabotegravir ( Apretude ), is a shot you get from your doctor or another health care provider. Your first two injections are given one month apart. After that, you need a shot every two months. Apretude is for people who are at risk of HIV through sex and who weigh 77 pounds or more. You must test negative for HIV before each Apretude injection.
The newest PrEP drug is lenacapavir (Yeztugo), which involves two injections every six months. It is also for people who are at risk of HIV through sex and who weigh 77 pounds or more.

content_blocks.text: The second pill, FTC/TAF (Descovy), isn't prescribed for those assigned female at birth. That's because it's unclear if the drug protects against HIV transmission if you have sex through your vagina.
Both and Descovy and Truvada are daily pills.

Another PrEP drug, cabotegravir ( Apretude ), is a shot you get from your doctor or another health care provider. Your first two injections are given one month apart. After that, you need a shot every two months. Apretude is for people who are at risk of HIV through sex and who weigh 77 pounds or more. You must test negative for HIV before each Apretude injection.
The newest PrEP drug is lenacapavir (Yeztugo), which involves two injections every six months. It is also for people who are at risk of HIV through sex and who weigh 77 pounds or more.

sections.heading: How Well Does PrEP Work?
content: If you take your PrEP medicine as directed, it works well against HIV transmission. You should be able to protect yourself from HIV infection from sexual contact 99% of the time (some people may not consistently take the medication). If you inject drugs and share needles, PrEP isn’t as effective, but can protect you in 74% of HIV exposures.

PrEP medicine doesn’t work as well if you miss doses. You must take it as directed in order to get the protection. In clinical trials, Apretude injections offered much stronger protection against HIV infections from sex than Truvada pills, and Yeztugo protected people the most from HIV infection.

sections.heading: Who’s Most Likely to Benefit From PrEP?
content: You’re most likely to benefit from PrEP if you don’t have HIV (are HIV-negative) but your sexual activity or drug use raises your risk of getting it.
Anyone can get HIV. You’re at greater risk for it if you:
So if you’re HIV-negative, you may want to talk to your doctor about PrEP if you have any of the risk factors listed above.

PrEP can help protect both you and your baby if you plan to get pregnant from a partner with HIV. It helps block the virus during pregnancy and while breastfeeding. Talk to your doctor about the best way to do this.
bullets: Have more than one sexual partner
Have anal sex
Have vaginal or anal sex without a condom
Have sex with anyone who has HIV
Share needles or syringes with someone who has HIV
Have (or have had recently) another sexually transmitted infection (STI), such as chlamydia, syphilis, gonorrhea , or herpes

content_blocks.text: You’re most likely to benefit from PrEP if you don’t have HIV (are HIV-negative) but your sexual activity or drug use raises your risk of getting it.
Anyone can get HIV. You’re at greater risk for it if you:

Have anal sex
Have vaginal or anal sex without a condom
Have sex with anyone who has HIV
Share needles or syringes with someone who has HIV
Have (or have had recently) another sexually transmitted infection (STI), such as chlamydia, syphilis, gonorrhea , or herpes

content_blocks.text: So if you’re HIV-negative, you may want to talk to your doctor about PrEP if you have any of the risk factors listed above.

PrEP can help protect both you and your baby if you plan to get pregnant from a partner with HIV. It helps block the virus during pregnancy and while breastfeeding. Talk to your doctor about the best way to do this.

sections.heading: Is PrEP a Vaccine?
content: No. A vaccine causes your body to make special substances called “antibodies” that fight against a disease-causing germ, like a virus, long after you take the dose.
PrEP protects you against HIV only as long as you continue to take your medicine. The effect disappears once you stop taking the medication.
PrEP also doesn’t prevent pregnancy or stop you from getting other sexually transmitted diseases, or STDs. The best way to protect against STDs like gonorrhea and chlamydia is to wear a condom.

content_blocks.text: No. A vaccine causes your body to make special substances called “antibodies” that fight against a disease-causing germ, like a virus, long after you take the dose.
PrEP protects you against HIV only as long as you continue to take your medicine. The effect disappears once you stop taking the medication.
PrEP also doesn’t prevent pregnancy or stop you from getting other sexually transmitted diseases, or STDs. The best way to protect against STDs like gonorrhea and chlamydia is to wear a condom.

sections.heading: What Are the Side Effects of PrEP?
content: Side effects are few and usually go away. Nausea is most common with the pills and happens in about 1 out of 10 people. You might also have a headache. In most cases, these symptoms disappear after a few weeks of use.
People who get Apretude or Yeztugo shots report side effects such as:
There are no serious or life-threatening side effects.
bullets: Reaction where the shot went in
Fever
Back or other pain
Rash

meta_description: PrEP (pre-exposure prophylaxis) is medicine that helps protect you from HIV, which causes AIDS. Learn about how it works, how well it works, who’s most likely to benefit from it, side effects, and more.
